newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Brussels blue-chip index seen taking cue from Dow.
newsitem.headline: Brussels blue-chip index seen taking cue from Dow.

text.p: Brussels Bel-20 index which closed down two percent on Tuesday was expected to take a cue from Wall Street in coming days, but traders said further falls in the U.S. were likely to trigger a major sell-off.
"It's wait-and-see for investors, if the Dow closes in positive territory it will boost the Bel-20 in coming days, but if it closes negative we'll plunge," said one trader.
The Brussels blue chip Bel-20 closed down 1.96 percent, or 42.08 points, at 2,104.29 after earlier falling over three percent.
Wall Street has fallen over four percent in the last two days of trade due to fears of further interest rate hikes.
Traders said investors were also eyeing U.S. NAPM figures for for an indication on U.S. rates.
"There's no panic in the market, a lot of players are on the sidelines but some market players are taking the opportunity to pick up cheap stocks," another trader said.
Financials were hardest hit as they are more likely to suffer from further U.S. interest rate hikes.
"Financials were under pressure, because of interest rate worries in the U.S.," trader Paul de Lophem at brokerage Mignon, Hanart, Declerck said.
Belgium's fourth-largest bank BBL fell 4.38 percent to 7,420 francs and insurer Royale Belge dropped 4.32 percent to 8,420 francs.
Financial group Fortis AG ended down 4.07 percent at 5,900 francs.
Elsewhere holding company Groupe Bruxelles Lambert (GBL) closed up 0.7 percent at 5,010 francs.

GBL and its unit Electrafina benefitted from news that several shareholders of French company Cie de Suez wanted Suez to distribute some of its cash ahead of a possible merger with Lyonnaise des Eaux.
Electrafina, which closed up 0.6 percent at 3,490 francs, owns 8.3 percent of Suez.
"GBL is positive because of the Suez story and the same stands for Electrafina," added de Lophem.
